subject: Why should I continue to use junit.swingui.TestRunner with JUnit 4.1 ?
msgSnippet: Hi, I d like to migrate to JUnit 4.1 definitely. Before (with JUnit 3.8), I used to execute my tests by three ways: 1- within Eclipse ; 2- with a junit task in
messageBody:
Hi,

I'd like to migrate to JUnit 4.1 definitely.

Before (with JUnit 3.8), I used to execute my tests by three ways:

1- within Eclipse ;
2- with a junit task in ant ;
3- with a java task in ant executing a junit.swingui.TestRunner class.

According to the 3.8 cookbook, if I wanted to run more than one tests
in one shot, I had to create a TestSuite including all my tests. So my
test classes which were placed all around beside my business classes
were all refered by a hierarchy of TestSuite classes up to the root
package of my project. It was working fine, but now, it's different.

With 4.1, it seems that the TestSuite is no more required. Then, I
decided to get rid of the TestSuite classes in my project. Anyway,
Eclipse (version 3.2.1) was complaining when I was trying to run the
tests each time it was encountering a TestSuite class. Now within
Eclipse, the only thing I have to do to run my tests is to click on
the package I want to test and to run it as a JUnit test; Eclipse
seems to gather all the test classes in this particular package and it
execute the tests within that package. If I want to run a particular
test, I just have to perform the same operation on that particular
test. That's great and it is working fine. It seems also that it
search all the tests in a hierarchical way, so I just have to "run as
a Junit" on the root package of my project to execute the whole bunch
of tests in my project.

The second way to execute the test was within ant. I commented out my
old junit target in my build.xml to change it the way they explain in
the FAQ.html (using the batchtest element) and it works well.

My problem is with the third way: using the junit.swingui.TestRunner
class present in the version 3.8. I say "present in..." because this
class isn't available anymore in the version 4.1. As I said in the
beginning of my post, I want to change to 4.1 definitely and I like to
know whether I have to forget the Swing GUI runner or not. I don't
want to include the java.jar of the previous version just to be able
to run that runner. The problem is I liked to run my tests outside
Eclipse using that special Swing test runner, but if someone tell me
the reasons why it has been removed, I'll try to forget to use it anymore.

In that case, I'll use Eclipse as a graphical user interface
environment to run my JUnit tests and I will use the console mode
throught ant to quickly verify my code.

Thanks for your advice,
Al
